Award.AwardTitle: IBSS-L: Continuous Measurement of Children's Behavior and the Development of Social Dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will investigate the development of children's social networks using real-time observations of classroom behavior. Continuous measurement of children's movements in the classroom will be complemented with automated analyses of audio recordings and human descriptions of social contacts. Children will be followed from toddler through pre-school to pre-kindergarten in order to conduct a longitudinal investigation of the origin and development of their social networks. Interactions will be observed across classroom activities and will include teachers, allowing for a comprehensive model of classroom ecology and gender segregation patterns. The project will enhance understanding about the micro-geography of educational practice to determine how student location is distributed with respect to the pedagogic structuring of classroom space, such as which children visit the book area together. The findings will provide a knowledge base designed to address deficits in school engagement that characterize the ethnically diverse and economically disadvantaged students who will be participating in the project. Project resources and de-identified data will be disseminated to the research community to facilitate additional discovery.

This project will unite network scientists from physics with developmental and school psychologists to investigate the development and dynamic functioning of social networks. Quantitative network models of social dynamics will be infused with information about the role that child characteristics like gender and ethnicity play in the formation of classroom social groups. Agent-based modeling will synthesize movement and social contact dynamics. Network models will be parameterized with fission-fusion equations to predict changes in children's developing social networks such as the size and gender composition of groups of interacting children. Multilevel models will capture within- and between- year longitudinal changes in sociality for individual children and for the network overall. These complementary models will specify the processes through which children's social groups become progressively larger and more interconnected over development. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A growing body of research captures the behaviors of individuals in real time to better understand social dynamics, but continuous, multimodal measurements of children’s interactions are rare. The current project investigated the development of children’s movement and social language networks using real-time, continuous observations of classroom behavior.

Objective mapping of children’s and teacher’s movements was complemented by automated analyses of their speech from individual audio recorders. Children and teachers in preschool classrooms wore vests containing first-person audio (LENA) recorders and two radio frequency identification (RFID, Ubisense) tags, which indicated the physical location and orientation of children and teachers. Each audio stream was processed by commercially available Gaussian mixture models to detect child, peer, and teacher vocalizations, and by Sphinx speech recognition software which utilizes hidden Markov Models to yield an index of the phonemic complexity (the number of unique consonant and vowel sounds) of these vocalizations. The project was the first to employ a data-driven approach, the pair correlation function [g(r)], to detect periods of social contact based on the co-location and reciprocal orientation of pairs of children (and children and teachers.

A central application focused on language development among typically hearing children  and children with hearing loss (HL) whose hearing loss is treated by hearing aids and cochlear implants. When children were in social contact (within 1.5 meters of one another and oriented roughly face-to-face), speech from peers in one observation predicted speech to peers in the next observation which, in turn, predicted assessed receptive and expressive language abilities. By way of validation, this objective measure of peer vocal interaction during social contact was associated with both teacher and child reports of friendship frequently used in classroom network analyses. In a similar fashion, the phonemic complexity of teacher’s speech predicted the phonemic complexity of children’s speech, which again predicted assessed receptive and expressive language abilities. The results suggest the importance of both peers and teachers in fostering vocal interactions that in turn support language development.

 

A second application concerned the social interaction and peer networks of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and their typically developing (TD) peers. Pairs of children in which one or both children had ASD approached each other more slowly than pairs of typically developing children. By contrast, children with ASD approached and were approached by their teachers more quickly than typically developing children. The results suggest that children with ASD have more fluid interactions with teachers than with peers. Likewise, a social language network captured the structure of these children’s vocal interactions with peers when in social contact. Network modularity comparisons indicated that there were fewer vocal interactions among children with ASD than there were among TD children. Moreover, vocal interactions between children with ASD and TD children were particularly low. Children’s degree centrality in these networks predicted their assessed language abilities. The results suggest that children with ASD benefit from social contact and vocal interaction with peers. However, lower levels of contact and vocal intercourse with peers may contribute to difficulties with language use and development.

With respect to intellectual merit, computational modeling of social contact and peer speech networks shed objective light on children’s interactions in preschool classrooms. Overall, talk with peers in social contact (and speech heard from teachers) promoted children's own talk which, in turn, was associated with assessed language abilities. Findings suggested complementary roles for peers and teachers in fostering the language and social development of diverse groups of children.

With respect to broader impacts, the educational inclusion of children with communication disorders together with typically developing peers is a national standard. Yet we have little mechanistic understanding of how interactions with peers and teachers contribute to children’s language development. To build that understanding, we combined objective measurement of the quantity and quality of child and teacher speech with radio frequency identification of their physical movement and orientation. Results were presented in peer reviewed journal articles, chapters, conference presentations, and invited addresses. Finally, the team conducted presentations to stakeholders where the research took place, and provided school district officials with the results of simulations of classroom movement data which predicted COVID19 infection outcomes.
